snippet: Promises of judicial reforms have gone largely unfulfilled, while practices adopted by the United States after the invasion in 2003 remain at the core of Sunni grievances.
abstract: Iraqi Prime Min Haider al-Abadi's promises of judicial reforms have gone largely unfulfilled, further upsetting Sunni minority who blame United States for rise of Islamic State.

byline.contributor: Omar Al-Jawoshy contributed reporting from Baghdad, and employees of The New York Times contributed reporting from Anbar and Diyala provinces.

lead_paragraph: Promises of judicial reforms have gone largely unfulfilled, while practices adopted by the United States after the invasion in 2003 remain at the core of Sunni grievances.

headline.main: Sunnis in Iraq Are Kept Waiting for Reforms, and Word on Loved Ones
headline.print_headline: Sunnis in Iraq Are Kept Waiting for Reforms, and Word on Loved Ones

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
